This looks pretty good!  A couple of things to polish it off for merging:
-  directory listings should be displayed sorted.  Alphabetically is fine for now, in future revisions a richer API for sorting could be added but let's not over-engineer for now.
- For `FileLinks`, when a directory contains subdirs, I think the recursive walking is great but there should be a visual cue that there's a subdir.  Otherwise it's hard to make out visually what comes from where.  Something like

```
foo.txt
bar.txt
[ Subdir name ]
foo2.txt
[ subdir/subdir]
foo3.txt
```

At least that would make the output in more complex cases far more usable than the current one.

These should be easy fixes to apply, and otherwise I think this is a great contribution.  Thanks!

Greg, thanks for fixing the directory issue.  One github/git tip.  When you create a commit message, use the following format:

```
One line summary of the commit

Longer description that gives further details.
```

This will ensure that the commits messages are formatted properly on github and the emails that github sends out.  The reason is that github uses the first line in the subject of emails and other UI elements on the website.

Overall this is looking good.  Is there anything else that needs to be done before this is merged?

One question though.  The whole display formatter logic seems pretty complex for such a simple class.  Can you summarize why that is needed.  I ask because it makes an otherwise simple class hard to follow.

I think this is ready for a merge when you guys are ready for it. We have a QIIME release on Dec 18th, so the sooner the better for us as we want this to be accessible in the AWS VM that we put out with the release, and we need time for testing.

The motivation for providing the display formatters as a function is that it's easier for users to customize how the output is formatted (e.g., @fperez suggested that we might want to support richer sorting functionality for the directory listings). This way users can format differently without subclassing `FileLink` or `FileLinks` (which I think would get ugly if we had a bunch of different options for formatting). We also need different formatting for the notebook and the terminal (i.e., HTML versus plain text), but most of the functionality is the same for both. Previously there was no `_get_display_formatter` method, and there was a lot of overlap between `_get_notebook_display_formatter` and `_get_terminal_display_formatter`. 

Does this answer your question?

I like to avoid adding complexity until it is actually needed, not just because it might someday be needed.  The most likely usage case is that someone adds _one_ option that controls how things are formatted.  We definitely have lots of other display classes that have a handful of options.  My problem with the design is that I can't look at the class and see that is does something super simple = take a file or directory and provide an HTML or text repr.

If the display formatters we lightweight functions, then I could imagine it would be nice to pass them into the class.  But they are somewhat complex and it is very likely - almost  for sure - that they would want to access helper methods of the class.  In such cases subclassing is a _perfect_ solution.

Even if you want to keep the current design, you have an extra layer of indirection that makes it difficult to find the actual formatting logic.  You define a `_get_display_formatter` method, that returns an inner-defined function that does the actual formatting.  Then you grab that function using code like this:

``` python
self.notebook_display_formatter = \ 
    notebook_display_formatter or self._get_notebook_display_formatter()
```

Why not put the default formatting logic in a method called `_default_notebook_display_formatter` and then simply set `self.notebook_display_formatter` to that method?

Also, I would prefer to use `HTML` rather than `notebook` formatter and `text` rather than `terminal` formatter.  The reason is that all formats are actually sent to all cients, so it is entirely possible that the notebook could display the text version.  Also, the QtConsole will also display the HTML format.  I was very confused to see language about the frontends appear in the display code and it took me a while to realize what was meant.

BUT, I realize that you want to get this merged quickly and non of this affects the public API of these classes.  I will leave it up to you to decide if you want to make any changes or merge as is.  If you do want to merge as is, please let me know and I will do that right away.

Let me see if I have time to take a crack at simplifying it this week, but if I run out of time I will take you up on your offer to merge and then clean up leaving the API as-is. More shortly, and thanks for detailed the feedback!
